Line 221: Line 221:
==== 3 February ====
==== 3 February ====
â
Egypt's Health Minister Ahmed Samih Farid said that during the previous day, 5 people had died in the fighting and 836 were injured - mostly as the result of stone-throwing and attacks with metal rods and sticks.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891 Anti-Mubarak protesters hit back], BBC, February 3, 2011.</ref>
+
Egypt's Health Minister Ahmed Samih Farid said that during the previous day, 5 people had died in the fighting and 836 were injured - mostly as the result of stone-throwing and attacks with metal rods and sticks.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12357891 Anti-Mubarak protesters hit back], BBC, February 3, 2011.</ref> Later he said eight people have died so far and 890 been injured, including nine in critical condition, in the Tahrir Square clashes.
A standoff took place in front of the Egyptian Museum in the early morning hours where rocks and petrol bombs were reported to be flying. Large-caliber shots were also reported to have been fired in the air by the army. There was also a heavy police presence at the museum following the standoff; and anti-government protesters were seen banging on metal railings while rocks were thrown at them. Pro-Mubarak protesters continued to throw Molotov cocktails at the anti-government demonstrators.<ref>[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/02/live-blog-feb-3-egypt-protests "Live blog 3 Feb - Egypt protests"] ''Al Jazeera Staff in Middle East'' - 2 February 2011 - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> There were also protests continuing in Alexandria and Mansoura, where ''Al Jazeera'' suggested up to a million people marched.<ref name="aljazlive"/>Egyptian army tanks cleared a highway overpass from which pro-Mubarak protesters had hurled rocks and firebombs onto the anti-Mubarak protesters. On the streets below, hundreds of armed soldiers lined up between the two forces, pushing the pro-Mubarak protesters back and blocking the main battle lines in front of the Egyptian Museum and at other entrances to the square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110203/D9L5DANO0.html Cairo square chaos intensifies, violence spreads]</ref>
A standoff took place in front of the Egyptian Museum in the early morning hours where rocks and petrol bombs were reported to be flying. Large-caliber shots were also reported to have been fired in the air by the army. There was also a heavy police presence at the museum following the standoff; and anti-government protesters were seen banging on metal railings while rocks were thrown at them. Pro-Mubarak protesters continued to throw Molotov cocktails at the anti-government demonstrators.<ref>[http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/02/live-blog-feb-3-egypt-protests "Live blog 3 Feb - Egypt protests"] ''Al Jazeera Staff in Middle East'' - 2 February 2011 - Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref> There were also protests continuing in Alexandria and Mansoura, where ''Al Jazeera'' suggested up to a million people marched.<ref name="aljazlive"/>Egyptian army tanks cleared a highway overpass from which pro-Mubarak protesters had hurled rocks and firebombs onto the anti-Mubarak protesters. On the streets below, hundreds of armed soldiers lined up between the two forces, pushing the pro-Mubarak protesters back and blocking the main battle lines in front of the Egyptian Museum and at other entrances to the square.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110203/D9L5DANO0.html Cairo square chaos intensifies, violence spreads]</ref>
